data.title: Alain Rossmann
data.meta_description: Alain Simon Rossmann (born 1956)[1] was an early member of the Macintosh team at Apple Computer. He became a serial entrepreneur who went on to found or co-found nine startups, of which three went public (Radius,[2] C-Cube Microsystems,[3] Unwired Planet[4]), three were acquired (EO by AT&T,[5...
data.text:
Alain Simon Rossmann (born 1956)[1] was an early member of the Macintosh team at Apple Computer. He became a serial entrepreneur who went on to found or co-found nine startups, of which three went public (Radius,[2] C-Cube Microsystems,[3] Unwired Planet[4]), three were acquired (EO by AT&T,[5] Vudu by Walmart,[6] PSS Systems by IBM[7]), and two were dissolved (Zonbu,[8] Klip[9]). The ninth is his current company, Machinify.[10][11]

Education[]

In 1979, Rossmann graduated at the École Polytechnique[12] [13][13] with a BS in mathematics and physics. He completed an MS in civil engineering at École Nationale des Ponts et Chaussées[12] in 1981 and an MBA from Stanford University in 1983.[11]

Career[]

Apple Computer and Silicon Valley[]

Rossmann was head evangelist at the Macintosh division of Apple Computer from 1983 to 1986.[11][14][15] He worked with Joanna Hoffman and the couple subsequently married.[16][17] Next, he co-founded Radius, a company that built Macintosh peripherals. He was vice-president of marketing and sales from 1986 to 1989.[2][11] Its IPO was in 1990.[18] He was vice-president of operations of C-Cube Microsystems, a leading developer of MPEG integrated circuits, from 1989 to 1992.[3] Its IPO was in 1994. It was acquired by LSI Logic in 2001.[19]

Mobile computing[]

Moving into pen computing, Rossmann was CEO of EO from 1992 to 1994. It built and marketed the EO Personal Communicator. It was acquired by AT&T Corporation in 1993.[5] With his colleague Celeste Baranski, he won the Discover Award from Discover Magazine in 1993 for this product.[20] In an early smartphone development, he was founder and CEO of Unwired Planet (later renamed Phone.com, then Openwave, then back to Unwired Planet) from 1994 to 2001. It developed the Wireless Application Protocol for smartphone microbrowsers.[21] Its IPO was in 1999.[4][22]

Information technology and online services[]

After Unwired Planet, he was founder and CEO then chairman of PSS Systems, an information lifecycle governance company, from June 2001 to October 2010. It was acquired by IBM in 2010.[7] His online movie service, Vudu, was acquired by Walmart.[6] He was founder and CEO from June 2005 to March 2010.[23] Next Rossmann was founder and chairman of Zonbu, subscription-based personal computer maker, from April 2006 to December 2007.[8] From March 2011 to January 2015 he worked at Klip, Inc., a social video start up, as founder and CEO.[9][11] Beginning January 2015 and to date, he is founder and chairman of Machinify. The company utilizes AI technology to help businesses digest their data and unlock hidden profits through automated decision-making. A software as a service platform is used that enables non-technical enterprises to build AI-powered products and processes.[10]
